nodes.html: • How You Can Use These Data

any.message: List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element
List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element

nodes.html: • Once every 24 hours, AluHunter downloads all new DNA that's been sequenced for a given taxon and submitted to NCBI GenBank.

any.message: List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element

nodes.html: • It searches the DNA for Alu insertions and adds all Alu elements to a database.

any.message: List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element

nodes.html: • It then grabs the flanking regions that surround the Alu insertion in the source DNA.

any.message: List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element

nodes.html: • Next AluHunter BLASTs the flanks against an outgroup genome or genomes, and decides if an Alu is present, absent, or indeterminate.

any.message: List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element

nodes.html: • For those Alu elements that are absent in the outgroup genome, it designs PCR primers from the flanks surrounding the Alu.

any.message: List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element

nodes.html: • All interesting Alu element's data and primers are uploaded into an online database, accessible through this website.

nodes.html: If two taxa share an Alu and a third does not, you know almost certainly that those first two taxa are more closely related to each other than they are to the third.

All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: Below is the sequence from a macaque (top) aligned with that of a Hamadryas baboon (bottom). Note the Alu-sized gap and the conserved flanking regions where a primer can sit.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: Since the Alu is present in two species of baboon, but not in the macaque, we can infer that this Alu was inserted on the lineage leading to baboons since the split with macaques, possibly in one of the following scenarios:

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: The Alu could have been inserted right after the baboon lineage split from the macaque lineage. It's then fixed in all African Papionins.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: The Alu could have been inserted right after the baboon lineage split from the macaque lineage. It's then fixed in all African Papionins.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: The Alu could have been inserted right after the baboon lineage split from the macaque lineage. It's then fixed in all African Papionins.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: Inserted a bit later, it would be present in some African Papionins, but not others. These Alus would be useful for systematics within the African Papionins, like for resolving mangabey phylogeny.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: Inserted a bit later, it would be present in some African Papionins, but not others. These Alus would be useful for systematics within the African Papionins, like for resolving mangabey phylogeny.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: It could have been inserted later still, and present just in the baboon genus Papio. These Alus would be useful for identifying members of this genus.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: It could have been inserted later still, and present just in the baboon genus Papio. These Alus would be useful for identifying members of this genus.

nodes.html: The most recent insertions would be present in some members of Papio, but not others. If the Alu is polymorphic within the genus, it can tell us something about species-level phylogeny of the baboons.

nodes.html: Below is the outcome of BLASTing the baboon Alu in the gel photo above against the macaque genome. The right and left flanks, which were separated by an Alu insertion in the original Hamadryas baboon sequence, are found right next to one another in the macaque.

nodes.html: AluHunter is a suite of computer programs that automate the task of finding potentially polymorphic Alu elements for use in primate phylogenetics. Broadly, the algorithm performs the following steps:

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: AluHunter is a suite of computer programs that automate the task of finding potentially polymorphic Alu elements for use in primate phylogenetics

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Once every 24 hours, AluHunter downloads all new DNA that's been sequenced for a given taxon and submitted to NCBI GenBank.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • It searches the DNA for Alu insertions and adds all Alu elements to a database.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • It then grabs the flanking regions that surround the Alu insertion in the source DNA.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Next AluHunter BLASTs the flanks against an outgroup genome or genomes, and decides if an Alu is present, absent, or indeterminate.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • For those Alu elements that are absent in the outgroup genome, it designs PCR primers from the flanks surrounding the Alu.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • All interesting Alu element's data and primers are uploaded into an online database, accessible through this website.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: If two taxa share an Alu and a third does not, you know almost certainly that those first two taxa are more closely related to each other than they are to the third.

nodes.html: Below is the sequence from a macaque (top) aligned with that of a Hamadryas baboon (bottom). Note the Alu-sized gap and the conserved flanking regions where a primer can sit.
nodes.failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  Element's background color could not be determined due to a background image

any.message: Element's background color could not be determined due to a background image

nodes.html: Since the Alu is present in two species of baboon, but not in the macaque, we can infer that this Alu was inserted on the lineage leading to baboons since the split with macaques, possibly in one of the following scenarios:
nodes.failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  Element's background color could not be determined due to a background image

any.message: Element's background color could not be determined due to a background image

nodes.html: The Alu could have been inserted right after the baboon lineage split from the macaque lineage. It's then fixed in all African Papionins.
nodes.failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  Element's background color could not be determined due to a background image

any.message: Element's background color could not be determined due to a background image

nodes.html: Inserted a bit later, it would be present in some African Papionins, but not others. These Alus would be useful for systematics within the African Papionins, like for resolving mangabey phylogeny.
nodes.failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  Element's background color could not be determined due to a background image

any.message: Element's background color could not be determined due to a background image

nodes.html: It could have been inserted later still, and present just in the baboon genus Papio. These Alus would be useful for identifying members of this genus.

nodes.html: The most recent insertions would be present in some members of Papio, but not others. If the Alu is polymorphic within the genus, it can tell us something about species-level phylogeny of the baboons.

nodes.html: AluHunter is a suite of computer programs that automate the task of finding potentially polymorphic Alu elements for use in primate phylogenetics. Broadly, the algorithm performs the following steps:
